definitions.definition: to take air into your lungs and send it out again through your nose or mouth

examples.text: He **breathed deeply** before speaking again.
The air was so cold we could hardly breathe.
She was beginning to breathe more easily.
He was breathing heavily after his exertions.
Most people don't realize that they are breathing polluted air.
Always breathe through your nose.
He was breathing raggedly, mouth open.
I can barely breathe here.
I can't breathe properly—I'm gasping for air!
They were both breathing hard from the steep climb.
Try to breathe normally.
He hardly dared breathe in case they heard him.
The men breathe air that is filtered to remove any dust or gas.

definitions.definition: to send a smell or sound, or air, smoke, etc. out of your mouth

examples.text: It's not polite to breathe garlic all over everybody.
I **breathed a** huge **sigh of relief**.
She rushed into my office breathing fire and threatening me with a lawyer.
‘I'm over here,’ she breathed.
You know I'd never **breathe a word** *(= tell a secret)* to anyone.
He breathed the words against her ear.
‘Where are you?’ breathed a voice in the dark.

definitions.definition: if you allow wine to breathe, you open the bottle and let air get in before you drink it
if cloth, leather, skin, etc. can breathe, air can move around or through it

examples.text: Cotton clothing allows your skin to breathe.

definitions.definition: to be full of a particular feeling or quality

examples.text: Her performance breathed wit and charm.

definitions.definition: to feel calm again after something unpleasant or frightening has ended

examples.text: Once he was safely back in prison, she was able to breathe easily again.

definitions.definition: to watch closely what somebody is doing in a way that makes them feel anxious and/or annoyed

examples.text: I can’t get any work done with you breathing down my neck.
You can rest easy—I'm not going to tell anyone.
I can sleep easy knowing that she's safely home.

definitions.definition: to improve something by introducing new ideas and making people more interested in it

examples.text: The results of their research have breathed new life into the debate.
He hopes the development will breathe new life into the community.
They need some new, younger staff to breathe some life into the company.

definitions.definition: to be very enthusiastic about something

examples.text: He just lives and breathes football.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘exhale, steam’): from breath.
